large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: A Friend Like You

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary (autumn, buried).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What are some ways we can make new friends?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Make connections between words and real life.
Try to use new words and grammar.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Separate sentences into words.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use picture prompts to help children talk about things that friends do together.
Examples include share, comfort, play ball, blow bubbles, play on the playground, and sing.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What characters are friends in that book?
Pretend to be Squirrel and the bird from A Friend Like You. Act out something you remember from the book.
How many friends do you have? Can you write the number?
Draw a picture of something you like to do with your best friend. How would you describe it?
Can you use the materials in the center to make a sculpture for one of your friends?
What is the name of a good friend of yours? What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of their name? Can you write the letter?
Use blocks to make a model of something that you and your friend can play with.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: A Friend Like You

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder initiate and join in play and introduce vocabulary (join, goal).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to A Friend Like You.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Follow oral directions.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Make connections between words and real life.
Try to use new words and grammar.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Separate sentences into words.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Listening; Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use pictures to learn which children enjoy the same activities.
Encourage children to use what they learn to find friends to play with during independent centers and outside time.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Show a picture of two good friends in a book.
Act like Squirrel did when he first heard the bird singing.
Count all the things you like to do with your friends. What is the number?
Draw a picture of something you remember from A Friend Like You. Can you tell a story about it?
Make up a fun game for you and a friend to play together.
What is the first sound you hear in the word friend? What letter makes that sound? Can you write it?
Build models of some of the things you and your friends like.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. A Friend Like You by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen, illustrated by Sean Julian. large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: A Friend Like You

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Listening; Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Listen and Remember and introduce vocabulary (delicious, climb).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question, What are some things that friends like to do together?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Follow oral directions.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Make connections between words and real life.
Try to use new words and grammar.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Separate sentences into words.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Explore pictures of food with children and sort them into “delicious” and “not delicious” categories.
Help children understand that friends can have different likes and dislikes.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Would you want to be friends with the character from that book? Why or why not?
Use movements to show me how you would welcome a friend.
Think of three different ways you can make a new friend. Let’s count them.
Draw a picture for a friend who is having a bad day.
Paint a picture of a favorite memory you have with a friend.
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word climb?
What are you building? Can you build something that you can use to play with a friend?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. A Friend Like You by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen, illustrated by Sean Julian. Text copyright © 2016 by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Sean Julian. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Tiger Tales, an imprint of Little Tiger Press Ltd.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Thank You, Friend!

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about friends, sing a song about friendship, and introduce vocabulary words (take turns, share).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Thank You, Friend! and A Friend Like You.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Follow oral directions.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Make connections between words and real life.
Try to use new words and grammar.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Separate sentences into words.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Listening; Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children to discuss and draw pictures about people they are thankful for.
Help them to create an “I am thankful for . . .” classroom display.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Why do you think the character in that book had so many friends?
Show me how good friends act with each other.
Find out how old some of your classmates are. Who is the oldest? Who is the youngest?
What would you write in an email to your friend?
Make a cover for your own “I Am Thankful for . . .” book. Draw some pictures of the things you are thankful for on the cover.
Say the word share. What is the first sound you hear? Can you show me the letters that make that sound?
Build two houses out of blocks so you and a friend can live next door to each other.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. A Friend Like You by Andrea Schomburg and Barbara Röttgen, illustrated by Sean Julian. large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Book: A Friend Like You

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Listening; Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children do an activity and introduce vocabulary (together, different).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What do you think is the most important thing about being a good friend?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Follow oral directions.
Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Make connections between words and real life.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Sentence Structure: Try to use new words and grammar (Multilingual Learners).

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Initiate play and join a group in play.
Separate sentences into words.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Listening; Conversation; Vocabulary; Sentence Structure

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: “What is your favorite thing about having good friends?”
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing/drawing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote your own book about being a good friend, what would be in it?
With a friend, pretend to be two animal friends.
Sort the things you like about your friends into different categories.
Create a drawing called “The Greatest Friend in the World.” Draw a picture to go with your story.
Work with some friends to create a group friendship mural.
Say the word together. What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word?
Create a Friendship Circle using blocks. Friends can sit inside the circle and play together.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Match language to social contexts
Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Attempt to use new vocabulary and grammar in speech.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Separate a normally spoken four-word sentence into individual words.
Use a variety of materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Follow two-step oral directions and usually follow three-step directions.
Match language to social contexts.
Attempt to use new vocabulary and grammar in speech.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Separate a normally spoken four-word sentence into individual words.
Create stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
